_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary
Sherman County Farm Chemicals & Fertilizer Co Inc
Wasco, Oregon

1.	Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Our facility primary activities include support services for crop production. We have anhydrous ammonia stored in one 21,500 gallon above ground tank and one 18,000 gallon above ground tank, at our facility in Wasco, Oregon. The maximum amount stored at our facility is 33,575 gallons (156,587 lbs).

2.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
Sherman County Farm Chemicals & Fertilizer Co is committed to the safety of our employees, the public and the environment. This commitment is an inherent part of our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers process areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance and employee training at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. We coordinate our response efforts with Sherman County Emergency Management and the North Sherman County Fire Protection District.

3.	Accidental Release Prevention program
Our facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the requirements set forth in 40 CFR, Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of our accidental release prevention program.

a.	Process Safety Information
Sherman County Farm Chemicals & Fertilizer Co maintains a detailed record of safety information describing the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the processes at our facility.

b.	Process Hazard Analysis
We conduct periodic reviews to ensure the hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled effectively. Findings from our Hazard Analysis reviews are addressed in a timely manner.

c.	Operating Procedures
We maintain written operating procedures to ensure that activities within our covered processes are conducted safely. Operating procedures are

reviewed periodically and updated as needed.

d.	Training
Sherman County Farm Chemicals & Fertilizer Co uses a comprehensive training program to ensure employees involved in our processes are competent in the operation and maintenance of our facilities. Employees receive annual training on the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. Employees also receive training if any updates or modifications are made to our facility that would affect operations or maintenance.

e.	Mechanical Integrity
Documented monthly facility inspections are conducted by trained and qualified employees. These inspections include the storage container and all related equipment. Maintenance is performed as needed and documented. 

f.	Program Compliance Audits
Periodic compliance audits are performed to ensure our program meets the requirements of 40 CFR, Part 68. Audits include all components of our Risk Management Program. Sherman County Farm Chemicals & Fertilizer Co  performs annual safety inspections and program compliance audits.

4.	Five-year Accident History
Sherman Farm Chemical maintained its History of No Accidents, and will continue to do So. Will continue to have training , and will strive for better documentation.
     
Emergency Response Plan
Sherman County Farm Chemicals & Fertilizer Co maintains a written Emergency Action Plan for our facility. The plan addresses emergency response issues including first aid, medical treatment and evacuation procedures. Information and procedures for contacting local response agencies (fire department, LEPC) are included in this plan.

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Sherman County Farm Chemicals & Fertilizer Co will continue to provide training as needed to employees involved in our covered processes. We will conduct monthly facility inspections to ensure our equipment and processes are safe. Deficiencies identified during audits and reviews will be addressed in a timely manner.
